title: When Machines Talk
text:
Preface
Somewhere in a packaging plant, five machines are humming.

 Image courtesy of jcomp, on Freepik

They fill, seal, label, count‚Ä¶
Ten thousand times a day, six days a week, fifty weeks a year. Quietly‚Ä¶
Nobody pays much attention. Until one stops. Then everyone pays very attention. üö®
Here‚Äôs the thing: they‚Äôve been talking all along.
Every start, every stop, every hiccup, every suspiciously long unplanned pause ‚Äî all of it logged. Timestamped. Waiting. 429,000 rows of it, across five machines and two years.
This series is about finally listening.
We‚Äôll go from ‚Äúwhat on earth is this column?‚Äù all the way to ‚Äúwait, can we actually predict when this thing is about to break down?‚Äù ‚Äî with R code, real numbers, and the occasional raised eyebrow at what the data reveals.
No prior knowledge of data science required. Some tolerance for R code recommended. A vague familiarity with the concept of a machine that occasionally misbehaves: mandatory.

A note on the data: I‚Äôd have loved to show you logs from a real plant I‚Äôve worked with. Instead, here‚Äôs a dataset from Kaggle that is, frankly, a very decent replacement : Packaging Industry Anomaly Detection. Real enough to be interesting. Anonymised enough that nobody gets fired.
Stack : R, tidyverse, Quarto Code : github.com/ArnaudCoqueblin/when-machines-talk

Six episodes. Five machines. One question: what were they trying to tell us?

title: What‚Äôs Next
text:
This series unfolds in 6 episodes ‚Äî each one building on the previous.

Next episode dropping soon.
